div.p: 1. The most current general word for physical shadowiness and obscurity is probably yōu 幽 (ant. míng 明 "bright"), but this word often has lyrical overtones of secluded peace.
2. Míng 冥 (ant. guāng 光 "light"), hūn 昏 (ant. zhāo 昭 "bright") and the rarer mèi 昧 (ant. xiǎn 顯 "clear and manifest") refer freely to purely optical darkness and abstract obscurity.
3. Xuán 玄 "very dark reddish-black" (ant. bái 白 "plain white") currently refers to mysterious obscurity of the abstract kind. See MYSTERIOUS
4. Huì 晦 (ant. zhāng 彰 "plain and manifest") refers to obscurity, expecially of texts or of thoughts.
5. Měng 蒙 (ant. yào 耀 "bright and clearly visible") refers to psychological dimness, obfuscation of mind.
6. Yǐn 隱 focuses on the inaccessibility to discursive reasoning of what is mysterious.
7. Àn 暗 / 闇 (ant. míng 明 "bright") can refer to darkness but most of the time this word actually refers abstractly to the benightedness of a ruler.
8. Yīn 陰 "shadowy, shaded" (ant.* liàng 亮 "bright") describes the lack of light as contrasted with surrounding light.
9. Ài 曖 is pervasive darkness as a general state, where mèi 昧 is darker than ài 曖.
10. Hēi 黑 (ant.* hào 皓 "shiny and bright") is darkness imposed by the intrinsic darkness of pigment on an object. See BLACK.
11. Yǎo 杳 is used in poetry as a general word referring to darkness.
12. Wū 烏 (ant. hào 皓 "shining white") is quite rare and refers to a high degree of darkness that is without lustre not quite pitch dark.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

bibl.title: Novyj objasnitel'nyj Slovar' Sinonimov Russkogo Jazyka

note.p: obscurum refers to darkness as an obstruction of light.
tenebrae refers directly to the absence of light as such.
caligo denotes a greater degree of darkness than tenebrae.

bibl.title: “荀子”單音節形容詞同義關係研究
Handbuch der lateinischen und griechischen Synonymik
Etymological Dictionary of Latin and the Other Italic Languages

note.p: Derivatives: caligare 'to be dark' (maybe Pac.+ 'to make dark' (uncertain

entry.def: Míng 冥 (ant. guāng 光 "light"), hūn 昏 (ant. zhāo 昭 "bright") and the rarer mèi 昧 (ant. xiǎn 顯 "clear and manifest") refer freely to purely optical darkness and abstract obscurity.

sense.def: be very obscure, dark, murky, and mystifying
dark and mysterious, like the night

entry.def: The most current general word for physical shadowiness and obscurity is probably yōu 幽 (ant. míng 明 "bright"), but this word often has lyrical overtones of secluded peace.

sense.def: the sphere of dark invisibility; the underworld
dark and shady, dark and secluded (like a shadowy valley); overgrown
be all dark; be completely secluded
be dark and shady, be secluded
cause to be dark and uncivilised

entry.def: Míng 冥 (ant. guāng 光 "light"), hūn 昏 (ant. zhāo 昭 "bright") and the rarer mèi 昧 (ant. xiǎn 顯 "clear and manifest") refer freely to purely optical darkness and abstract obscurity.

sense.def: dark and obscure;by extension: confused; benighted; obscured
be murky, be dim; be dusky by extension: be confused, benighted
when it is dark 昏者

entry.def: Míng 冥 (ant. guāng 光 "light"), hūn 昏 (ant. zhāo 昭 "bright") and the rarer mèi 昧 (ant. xiǎn 顯 "clear and manifest") refer freely to purely optical darkness and abstract obscurity.

sense.def: feel that one is in the dark, feel stupid
cause to be in the dark > conceal, obscure
be in complete darkness, find oneself completely in the dark

entry.def: Huì 晦 (ant. zhāng 彰 "plain and manifest") refers to obscurity, expecially of texts or of thoughts.
Àn 暗/闇 (ant. míng 明 "bright") can refer to darkness but most of the time this word actually refers abstractly to the benightedness of a ruler.
Àn 暗/闇 (ant. míng 明 "bright") can refer to darkness but most of the time this word actually refers abstractly to the benightedness of a ruler.

sense.def: state of darkness, state of darkness

entry.def: Ài 曖 is pervasive darkness as a general state, where mèi 昧 is darker than ài 曖.

sense.def: rare and poetic heavily overclouded and dark; cloudy and pregnant with rain, dark and rich
be dark and heavy with rain

entry.def: Yǎo 杳 is used in poetry as a general word referring to darkness.
Wū 烏 (ant. hào 皓 "shining white") is quite rare and refers to a high degree of darkness that is without lustre not quite pitch dark.
Xuán 玄 "very dark reddish-black" (ant. bái 白 "plain white") currently refers to mysterious obscurity of the abstract kind. See MYSTERIOUS

sense.def: what is very dark purple (the colour taken to be that of Heaven)

entry.def: Měng 蒙 (ant. yào 耀 "bright and clearly visible") refers to psychological dimness, obfuscation of mind.
Yīn 陰 "shadowy, shaded" (ant.* liàng 亮 "bright") describes the lack of light as contrasted with surrounding light.

sense.def: to get dark; get cloudy (of sky)
cause (ruler) to be in the dark, keep in the dark

entry.def: Yǐn 隱, and mì 秘 focus on the inaccessibility to discursinve reasoning of what is mysterious.

sense.def: be prone to hiding things from others; be mysterious and enigmatic

entry.def: Hēi 黑 (ant.* hào 皓 "shiny and bright") is darkness imposed by the intrinsic darkness of pigment on an object. See BLACK.

sense.def: be undistinguished, be less than well-known
